complex number, then z can be expressed as x + y i, where x, y are real
numbers, called the real and imaginary parts of z, and i2 = −1. In this case

These notes are connected to the "potpourri" topics class in the Department of Mathematics, Rice University, in the fall semester of 2004.

 2

Separation theorems

Fix a positive integer n, and let E be a nonempty closed convex subset of
Rn . Also let p be a point in Rn which is not in E. There exists a point q ∈ E
such that the Euclidean distance kp − qk2 from p to q is as small as possible.
Let H be the affine hyperplane through q which is orthogonal to p − q.
In other words, using the standard inner product on Rn , H consists of the
v ∈ Rn such that the inner product of v − q with p − q is equal to 0.
If x is any element of E, then x lies in the closed half-space in Rn which
is bounded by H and which does not contain p. This is equivalent to saying
that the inner product of x − q with p − q is less than or equal to 0, while
the inner product of p − q with itself is equal to kp − qk22 > 0. One can see
this through a simple geometric argument, to the effect that if x ∈ E lies in
the open half-space in Rn containing p, then there is a point along the line
segment joining x to q which is closer to p than q is.
It follows that in fact E is equal to the intersection of the closed halfspaces containing it. Namely, each point in Rn which is not in E is also in
the complement of one of the closed half-spaces containing E.
Remark 2.1 The use of the Euclidean norm here may seem a bit strange,
since the statement that q ∈ E and H is a hyperplane through q such that
E is contained in a closed half-space in Rn bounded by H and p is in the
complementary open half-space bounded by H does not require the Euclidean
norm or inner product. One could just as well use a different inner product
on Rn , which could lead to a different choice of q and H. Observe however
that if q and H the properties just mentioned, then there is an inner product
on Rn such that the distance from q to p in the corresponding norm is as
small as possible and H is the hyperplane through q which is orthogonal to
q − p.
Next suppose that E is a closed convex subset of Rn and that p is a
point in the boundary of E. Thus p ∈ E and there is a sequence of points

3

Dual spaces

Let V be a finite-dimensional real or complex vector space, and let V ∗ denote
the corresponding dual vector space of linear functionals on V . Thus the
elements of V ∗ are linear mappings from V into the real or complex numbers,
as appropriate. If V is a real or complex vector space, then V ∗ is too, because
one can add linear functionals and multiply them by scalars.
Suppose that the dimension of V is equal to n, and that v1 , . . . , vn is a
basis for V . Thus every element of V can be expressed in a unique manner as
a linear combination of the vj 's. If λ ∈ V ∗ , then λ is uniquely determined by
the n scalars λ(v1 ), . . . , λ(vn ), and these scalars may be chosen freely. Thus
8

 V ∗ also has dimension equal to n.

seen, any norm on Rn or Cn is equivalent to the standard Euclidean norm,
in the sense that each is bounded by a constant multiple of the other. The
existence of an k ≥ 0 as above then follows from the corresponding statement
for the Euclidean norm.

Now suppose that V is a complex vector space. If λ is a linear mapping
from V to the complex numbers, then the real part of λ is a real-linear
mapping from V into the real numbers, i.e., it is a linear functional on V as
a real vector space, without the additional structure of scalar multiplication
by i. Conversely, if one starts with a real-linear mapping from V into the
real numbers, then that is the real part of a unique complex-linear mapping
from V into the complex numbers, as one can verify.
If β is any complex number, then the modulus of β can be described as the
supremum of the real part of α β, where α runs through all complex numbers
with |α| ≤ 1. As a result, if V is a complex vector space, k * k is a norm on
V , and λ is a complex linear functional on V , then the dual norm of λ can be
described equivalently as the supremum of the real part of α λ(z) as α runs
through all complex numbers with |α| ≤ 1 and z runs through all vectors in
V with kzk ≤ 1. Hence the dual norm of λ is equal to the supremum of the
real part of λ(z) as z runs through all vectors in V with kzk ≤ 1, because
one can absorb the scalar factors into z. In other words, the norm of λ as a
complex linear functional on V is equal to the norm of the real part of λ as a
real linear functional on V , using the same norm on V . This permits one to

4

Quotient spaces, norms

Let V be a finite-dimensional real or complex vector space, and let W be a
linear subspace of V . Consider the quotient space V /W , which is basically
defined by identifying points in V whose difference lies in W . There is a
canonical quotient mapping q, which is a linear mapping from V onto W .
Suppose also that V is equipped with a norm kvk. Thus we get a metric
associated to this norm, and with respect to this metric W is a closed subset
of V . Indeed, in Rn or Cn , every linear subspace is a closed subset. The
general case can be derived from this one because V is isomorphic to Rn or
Cn for some n, and the norm on V is equivalent to the usual Euclidean norm
on Rn or Cn , as appropriate, with respect to this isomorphism.
Let us define a quotient norm k * kV /W on V /W by saying that the norm
of a point in V /W is equal to the infimum of the norms of the points in
V which are identified to that point in the quotient. Equivalently, for each
x ∈ V , the norm of q(x) in V /W is equal to the infimum of the norms of
x + w in V over w ∈ W . In particular, kq(x)kV /W ≤ kxk for all x ∈ V . It
is not difficult to check that this does indeed define a norm on the quotient
space V /W .
Now let Z be a linear subspace of V , and suppose that λ is a linear
functional on Z. We would like to extend λ to a linear functional on V
whose dual norm on V is the same as that of λ on Z, using the restriction
of the given norm on V to Z as a norm on Z. We may as well assume that
λ is not the zero linear functional, which is to say that λ(z) 6= 0 for at least
some z ∈ Z. Let W denote the kernel of λ, which is the linear subspace of
Z consisting of all vectors y ∈ Z such that λ(y) = 0.
Let us work in the quotient space V /W . The quotient Z/W is a onedimensional subspace of V /W . Because W is the kernel of λ, there is a
canonical linear functional on Z/W induced by λ. One can check that the
norm of this linear functional on Z/W , associated to the quotient norm on
Z/W obtained from our original norm k * k on V , is equal to the norm of λ
as a linear functional on Z.
Because Z/W has dimension equal to 1, there is a linear functional μ
on V /W with dual norm equal to 1 with respect to the quotient norm on
11

 V /W such that for each element of Z/W , the absolute value or modulus
of μ applied to that element is equal to the quotient norm of that element.
This follows from the result discussed in Section 3, applied to V /W with
the dual norm. We can multiply μ by a scalar to get a linear functional
on V /W whose norm is equal to the norm of λ on Z and which agrees on
Z/W with the linear functional induced there by λ. The composition of this
linear functional on V /W with the canonical quotient mapping from V onto
W gives a linear functional on V which extends λ from Z to V and has the
same norm as λ has on Z.

5

Dual cones

Let V be a finite-dimensional real vector space, and let C be a closed convex cone in V . To be more precise, one can use an isomorphism between V
and Rn to define the topology on V , i.e., so that the vector space isomorphism is a homeomorphism. This topology does not depend on the choice
of isomorphism with Rn , because every invertible linear mapping on Rn defines a homeomorphism from Rn onto itself. Thus C is a closed subset of V
which contains 0 and has the property that s v + t w ∈ V whenever s, t are
nonnegative real numbers and v, w ∈ C.
Let us define C ∗ to be the set of linear functionals λ on V such that
λ(v) ≥ 0 for all v ∈ C. One can check that C ∗ defines a closed convex cone in
V ∗ . This is called the dual cone associated to C. It follows from the result in
Section 2 for closed convex cones that C is actually equal to the set of v ∈ V
such that λ(v) ≥ 0 for all λ ∈ C ∗ .
As a basic example, let V be Rn for some positive integer n, and let C be
the closed convex cone consisting of vectors v = (v1 , . . . , vn ) such that vj ≥ 0
for all j. For each w ∈ Rn , we get a linear functional λw on Rn by putting
P
λw (v) = nj=1 vj wj , and every linear functional on Rn arises in this manner.
For this cone C, the dual cone C ∗ consists of the linear functionals λw such
that w ∈ C, as one can readily verify.
Now let W be a finite-dimensional real or complex vector space equipped
with an inner product hw, zi, and let V be the real vector space of linear
mappings A from W to itself which are self-adjoint, which is to say that
hA(w), zi is equal to hw, A(z)i for all w, z ∈ W . A self-adjoint linear transformation A on W is said to be nonnegative if hA(w), wi is nonnegative real
number for all w ∈ W , and the nonnegative self-adjoint linear transforma12

linear transformations on V . If T is a self-adjoint linear transformation on
V , then we get a linear functional λT on the vector space of self-adjoint linear transformations on W by setting λT (A) equal to the trace of A ◦ T for
any self-adjoint linear transformation A on W , and every linear functional
on the vector space of self-adjoint linear transformations on W arises in this
manner. If T is a self-adjoint linear transformation on W , then λT (A) ≥ 0
for all nonnegative self-adjoint linear transformations A on W if and only if
T is nonnegative. This can be verified using the fact that a self-adjoint linear
transformation on W can be diagonalized in an orthonormal basis.

6

Operator norms

Let V , W be finite-dimensional vector spaces, both real or both complex,
and let L(V, W ) be the vector space of linear mappings from V to W . More
precisely, this is a real vector space if V , W are real vector spaces and it is
a complex vector space if V , W are complex vector spaces. Notice that the
dual V ∗ of V is the same as L(V, R) when V is a real vector space and it is
the same as L(V, C) when V is a complex vector space.
Suppose that V , W are equipped with norms kvkV , kwkW . If T is a linear
mapping from V to W , then there is a nonnegative real number k such that
(6.1)

kT (v)kW ≤ k kvkV

for all v ∈ V . This can be derived from the case of mappings between
Euclidean spaces in the usual manner, and it basically amounts to saying
that T is continuous as a mapping from V to W with respect to the metrics
associated to the norms on V , W .
We define the operator norm of T as a linear mapping from V to W by
(6.2)

kT kop,V W = sup{kT (v)kW : v ∈ V, kvkV ≤ 1}.

Equivalently, kT kop,V W is the smallest nonnegative real number that one can
use as k in the preceding paragraph. It is easy to see that kT kop,V W does
indeed define a norm on L(V, W ). In the case where W is equal to R or C,
so that L(V, W ) is equal to V ∗ , the operator norm reduces to the dual norm
of a linear functional as defined in Section 3.
As another equivalent definition, the operator norm of T is equal to the
supremum of |μ(T (v))| over v ∈ V , μ ∈ W ∗ where the V -norm of v and the
13

 W ∗ -norm of μ are each less than or equal to 1. That |μ(T (v))| is less than or
equal to the operator norm of T for these v's and μ's follows easily from the
definition. The operator norm is equal to the supremum of these quantities
because norms in W are detected by linear functionals as in Section 3.
For each linear mapping T from V to W there is an associated dual linear
mapping T ∗ from W ∗ to V ∗ , defined by saying that if μ is a linear functional
on W , then T ∗ (μ) is the linear functional on V given by the composition of
μ with T . One can check that the operator norm o T ∗ , with respect to the

the original norms on V , W .

Fix p, 1 ≤ p < ∞, and a positive integer n. Let Sn−1 denote the standard
unit sphere in Rn equipped with the Euclidean norm, which is the compact
set of vectors with Euclidean norm equal to 1. Let V be the vector space of

We can define a p-norm on V by taking the integral of the pth power of
the absolute value of a continuous real-valued function on Sn−1 , and then
taking the (1/p)th power of the result. Here we use the standard element of
integration on Sn−1 which is invariant under rotations, and which one may
wish to normalize so that the total measure of the sphere is equal to 1.
If T is a linear transformation acting on real-valued functions on E, then
we get a linear transformation acting on V -valued functions as before. The

Let L denote the linear subspace of V consisting of functions on Sn−1

norm on Rn . Using this it follows that if T is a linear operator acting on
